title: 104_s1241
content: The Act is titled the "Public Broadcasting Financial Independence and Family Viewing Act of 1995". It amends Section 396(g)(1)(A) of title 47 to include language about family viewing. It adds a new section 396(k)(1)(F) stating that no Federal funds can be used to broadcast indecent or nudity-inclusive dramatic programs. The Act prohibits the use of Federal funds to broadcast indecent or nudity-inclusive programs. It also emphasizes the public interest in providing family-friendly programming on public broadcasting. The Commission can regulate public broadcast license holders to offer ancillary services on their spectrum as long as they continue to provide free public broadcast programming. Proceeds from these services must benefit public broadcasting, and licensees must maintain their commitment to public broadcasting. The Commission can regulate public broadcast license holders to offer ancillary services on their spectrum, ensuring that proceeds benefit public broadcasting and licensees maintain their commitment. Fees for non-public broadcasting use must be at market rates. SEC. 6. SCHEDULE FLEXIBILITY. The Commission can adopt regulations allowing public broadcast license holders to offer non-public broadcast programming for a fee between 1 a.m. and 6 a.m., as long as the proceeds benefit public broadcasting, existing commitments are maintained, and fees for non-public broadcasting are at market rates. SEC. 7. ENHANCED UNDERWRITING. Section 399(a) of title 47 is amended to remove the word "exclusive" and add language allowing for calls to action, inducements to buy, sell, rent, or lease, and the provision of price information. Section 399B(a) of title 47 is also amended to include similar language regarding promotions, with exceptions for educational or cultural events sponsored in part by a qualified entity. SEC. 8. SATELLITE, COMMON CARRIER AND OTHER FORMS OF PROGRAM DISTRIBUTION. Section 399B(a) of title 47 is amended to include language allowing for calls to action, inducements to buy, sell, rent, or lease, and the provision of price information, with exceptions for certain events sponsored by qualified entities. Public Broadcasting programming can be distributed via satellite, common carrier, or other telecommunications technology for a fee, with proceeds benefiting public broadcasting. The Commission can approve frequency exchanges between public and commercial broadcasters if the proceeds benefit the national public broadcasting system. Additionally, ancillary income is addressed. The Commission can approve frequency exchanges between public and commercial broadcasters if the proceeds benefit the national public broadcasting system. The Board of Directors of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the Public Broadcasting System must ensure that programming agreements include provisions for public broadcasting to share in benefits from ancillary products. The General Accounting Office will review the operations of public broadcasting entities and make recommendations for improvement within one year. Additionally, the feasibility of a merger with international broadcasting will be considered. The General Accounting Office will conduct a feasibility study on merging public broadcasting operations with international broadcasting. Public broadcast licensees may qualify for educational telecommunication service rates for broadcasting purposes.
